console_handler.description: Log handler that prints log events to the EMQX console.
console_handler.label: Console Handler

cacertfile.description: </br>Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.</br>The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates.</br>Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted.</br>There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because</br>the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).</br>NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect</br>already established connections.</br>
cacertfile.label: CACertfile

certfile.description: </br>PEM format certificates chain file.</br>The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate</br>issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning</br>of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on.</br>Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of</br>the file if it is to be added.</br>
certfile.label: Certfile

depth.description: </br>Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly; if 1 the path can be PEER, CA, ROOT-CA; if 2 the path can be PEER, CA, CA, ROOT-CA, and so on. The default value is 10.</br>
depth.label: CACert Depth

password.description: </br>String containing the user's password.</br>Only used if the private key file is password-protected.</br>
password.label: Keyfile passphrase

versions.description:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configured
['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.
versions.label: SSL versions

ciphers.description:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma,
or as an array of strings. e.g.
"TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or
["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].

Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the
client and server encrypts information over the network connection.
Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the
application's data security, confidentiality and performance.

The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format).
All default values and examples provided by EMQX config
documentation are all in OpenSSL format.

NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with
specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3')
incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped.
For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions,
configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.


NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384,
RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256,
RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA,
RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

user_lookup_fun.description: </br>EMQX-internal callback that is used to lookup pre-shared key (PSK) identity.</br>
user_lookup_fun.label: SSL PSK user lookup fun

secure_renegotiate.description: </br>SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server</br>to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.</br>RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,</br>you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.</br>
secure_renegotiate.label: SSL renegotiate

dhfile.description:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters
to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman
key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters
are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.
dhfile.label: SSL dhfile

fail_if_no_peer_cert.description: </br>Used together with {verify, verify_peer} by an TLS/DTLS server.</br>If set to true, the server fails if the client does not have a</br>certificate to send, that is, sends an empty certificate.</br>If set to false, it fails only if the client sends an invalid</br>certificate (an empty certificate is considered valid).</br>
fail_if_no_peer_cert.label: SSL fail if no peer cert

honor_cipher_order.description: </br>An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based</br> on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,</br> hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security</br> ordering of the server administrator.</br>
honor_cipher_order.label: SSL honor cipher order

client_renegotiation.description: </br>In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,</br>the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.</br>This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.</br>The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,</br>but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.</br>The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in</br>long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on</br>the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.</br>
client_renegotiation.label: SSL client renegotiation

handshake_timeout.description: </br>Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete</br>
handshake_timeout.label: Handshake timeout

cpu_check_interval.description: The time interval for the periodic CPU check.
cpu_check_interval.label: The time interval for the periodic CPU check.

cpu_high_watermark.description: The threshold, as percentage of system CPU load,</br> for how much system cpu can be used before the corresponding alarm is raised.
cpu_high_watermark.label: CPU high watermark

cpu_low_watermark.description: The threshold, as percentage of system CPU load,</br> for how much system cpu can be used before the corresponding alarm is cleared.
cpu_low_watermark.label: CPU low watermark

mem_check_interval.description: The time interval for the periodic memory check.
mem_check_interval.label: Mem check interval

sysmem_high_watermark.description: The threshold, as percentage of system memory,</br> for how much system memory can be allocated before the corresponding alarm is raised.
sysmem_high_watermark.label: SysMem high wartermark

procmem_high_watermark.description: The threshold, as percentage of system memory,</br> for how much system memory can be allocated by one Erlang process before</br> the corresponding alarm is raised.
procmem_high_watermark.label: ProcMem high wartermark

auto_reconnect.label: Auto Reconnect Database

seeds.label: Cluster Static Seeds

strategy.description: Dispatch strategy for shared subscription.</br>- `random`: dispatch the message to a random selected subscriber</br>- `round_robin`: select the subscribers in a round-robin manner</br>- `sticky`: always use the last selected subscriber to dispatch,</br>until the subscriber disconnects.</br>- `hash`: select the subscribers by the hash of `clientIds`</br>- `local`: send to a random local subscriber. If local</br>subscriber was not found, send to a random subscriber cluster-wide</br>
strategy.label: strategy

enable.description: Enable this log handler.
enable.label: Enable Log Handler

level.description: </br>The log level for the current log handler.</br>Defaults to warning.</br>
level.label: Log Level

time_offset.description:
The time offset to be used when formatting the timestamp.
Can be one of:
- system: the time offset used by the local system
- utc: the UTC time offset
- +-[hh]:[mm]: user specified time offset, such as "-02:00" or "+00:00"
Defaults to: system.
time_offset.label: Time Offset

chars_limit.description: Set the maximum length of a single log message. If this length is exceeded, the log message will be truncated.
chars_limit.label: Single Log Max Length

formatter.description: Choose log formatter. text for free text, and json for structured logging.
formatter.label: Log Formatter

single_line.description: Print logs in a single line if set to true. Otherwise, log messages may span multiple lines.
single_line.label: Single Line Mode

sync_mode_qlen.description: As long as the number of buffered log events is lower than this value,</br>all log events are handled asynchronously. This means that the client process sending the log event,</br>by calling a log function in the Logger API, does not wait for a response from the handler</br>but continues executing immediately after the event is sent.</br>It is not affected by the time it takes the handler to print the event to the log device.</br>If the message queue grows larger than this value,</br>the handler starts handling log events synchronously instead,</br>meaning that the client process sending the event must wait for a response.</br>When the handler reduces the message queue to a level below the sync_mode_qlen threshold,</br>asynchronous operation is resumed.</br>
sync_mode_qlen.label: Queue Length before Entering Sync Mode

drop_mode_qlen.description: When the number of buffered log events is larger than this value, the new log events are dropped.</br>When drop mode is activated or deactivated, a message is printed in the logs.
drop_mode_qlen.label: Queue Length before Entering Drop Mode

flush_qlen.description: If the number of buffered log events grows larger than this threshold, a flush (delete) operation takes place.</br>To flush events, the handler discards the buffered log messages without logging.
flush_qlen.label: Flush Threshold

supervisor_reports.description:
Type of supervisor reports that are logged. Defaults to error

- progress: log process startup.
supervisor_reports.label: Report Type

max_depth.description: Maximum depth for Erlang term log formatting and Erlang process message queue inspection.
max_depth.label: Max Depth

bind.label: IP address and port

acceptors.description: </br>The size of the listener's receiving pool.</br>
acceptors.label: Acceptors Num

max_connections.description: </br>The maximum number of concurrent connections allowed by the listener.</br>
max_connections.label: Max connections

mountpoint.description:
When publishing or subscribing, prefix all topics with a mountpoint string.
The prefixed string will be removed from the topic name when the message
is delivered to the subscriber. The mountpoint is a way that users can use
to implement isolation of message routing between different listeners.
For example if a client A subscribes to `t` with `listeners.tcp..mountpoint`
set to `some_tenant`, then the client actually subscribes to the topic
`some_tenant/t`. Similarly, if another client B (connected to the same listener
as the client A) sends a message to topic `t`, the message is routed
to all the clients subscribed `some_tenant/t`, so client A will receive the
message, with topic name `t`.
Set to `""` to disable the feature.

Variables in mountpoint string:
- ${clientid}: clientid
- ${username}: username
mountpoint.label: mountpoint

server_context_takeover.description: </br>Takeover means the compression state is retained between server messages.</br>

client_context_takeover.description: </br>Takeover means the compression state is retained between client messages.</br>
client_context_takeover.label: Client context takeover

server_max_window_bits.description: </br>Specifies the size of the compression context for the server.</br>
server_max_window_bits.label: Server compression max window size

client_max_window_bits.description: </br>Specifies the size of the compression context for the client.</br>
client_max_window_bits.label: Client compression max window size

active_n.description: </br>Specify the {active, N} option for this Socket.</br>See: https://erlang.org/doc/man/inet.html#setopts-2</br>

backlog.description: </br>TCP backlog defines the maximum length that the queue of</br> pending connections can grow to.</br>

send_timeout.description: </br>The TCP send timeout for the connections.</br>

high_watermark.label: TCP

max_size.description: This parameter controls log file rotation. The value `infinity` means the log file will grow indefinitely, otherwise the log file will be rotated once it reaches `max_size` in bytes.
max_size.label: Rotation Size

crash_dump_seconds.description: The number of seconds that the broker is allowed to spend writing a crash dump.
crash_dump_seconds.label: Crash Dump Seconds

crash_dump_bytes.description: The maximum size of a crash dump file in bytes.
crash_dump_bytes.label: Crash Dump Bytes

dist_net_ticktime.description: This is the approximate time an EMQX node may be unresponsive until it is considered down and thereby disconnected.
dist_net_ticktime.label: Dist Net TickTime

backtrace_depth.description:
Maximum depth of the call stack printed in error messages and
process_info.
backtrace_depth.label: BackTrace Depth

applications.description: List of Erlang applications that shall be rebooted when the EMQX broker joins the cluster.</br>
applications.label: Application

db_backend.description:
Select the backend for the embedded database.
rlog is the default backend,
that is suitable for very large clusters.
mnesia is a backend that offers decent performance in small clusters.
db_backend.label: DB Backend

db_role.description:
Select a node role.
core nodes provide durability of the data, and take care of writes.
It is recommended to place core nodes in different racks or different availability zones.
replicant nodes are ephemeral worker nodes. Removing them from the cluster
doesn't affect database redundancy
It is recommended to have more replicant nodes than core nodes.
Note: this parameter only takes effect when the backend is set
to rlog.
db_role.label: DB Role

rpc_module.description: Protocol used for pushing transaction logs to the replicant nodes.
rpc_module.label: RPC Module

tlog_push_mode.description: </br>In sync mode the core node waits for an ack from the replicant nodes before sending the next</br>transaction log entry.</br>
tlog_push_mode.label: Tlog Push Mode

default_shard_transport.description:
Defines the default transport for pushing transaction logs.
This may be overridden on a per-shard basis in db.shard_transports.
gen_rpc uses the gen_rpc library,
distr uses the Erlang distribution.
default_shard_transport.label: Default Shard Transport

shard_transports.description:
Allows to tune the transport method used for transaction log replication, on a per-shard basis.
gen_rpc uses the gen_rpc library,
distr uses the Erlang distribution.
If not specified,
the default is to use the value set in db.default_shard_transport.
shard_transports.label: Shard Transports

conn_congestion.description: Settings for `conn_congestion` alarm.</br></br>Sometimes the MQTT connection (usually an MQTT subscriber) may</br>get "congested", because there are too many packets to be sent.</br>The socket tries to buffer the packets until the buffer is</br>full. If more packets arrive after that, the packets will be</br>"pending" in the queue, and we consider the connection</br>congested.</br></br>Note: `sndbuf` can be set to larger value if the</br>alarm is triggered too often.</br>The name of the alarm is of format `conn_congestion/<ClientID>/<Username>`,</br>where the `<ClientID>` is the client ID of the congested MQTT connection,</br>and `<Username>` is the username or `unknown_user`.

cacertfile.label: CACertfile

certfile.description: </br>PEM format certificates chain file.</br>The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate</br>issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning</br>of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on.</br>Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of</br>the file if it is to be added.</br>

depth.description: </br>Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly; if 1 the path can be PEER, CA, ROOT-CA; if 2 the path can be PEER, CA, CA, ROOT-CA, and so on. The default value is 10.</br>

versions.description:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configured
['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.
versions.label: SSL versions

ciphers.description:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma,
or as an array of strings. e.g.
"TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or
["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].

Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the
client and server encrypts information over the network connection.
Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the
application's data security, confidentiality and performance.

The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format).
All default values and examples provided by EMQX config
documentation are all in OpenSSL format.

NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with
specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3')
incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped.
For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions,
configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.


NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384,
RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256,
RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA,
RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

user_lookup_fun.description: </br>EMQX-internal callback that is used to lookup pre-shared key (PSK) identity.</br>

secure_renegotiate.description: </br>SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server</br>to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.</br>RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,</br>you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.</br>
secure_renegotiate.label: SSL renegotiate

server_name_indication.description: </br>Specify the host name to be used in TLS Server Name Indication extension.</br>For instance, when connecting to "server.example.net", the genuine server</br>which accepts the connection and performs TLS handshake may differ from the</br>host the TLS client initially connects to, e.g. when connecting to an IP address</br>or when the host has multiple resolvable DNS records </br>If not specified, it will default to the host name string which is used</br>to establish the connection, unless it is IP addressed used.</br>The host name is then also used in the host name verification of the peer</br>certificate.</br> The special value 'disable' prevents the Server Name</br>Indication extension from being sent and disables the hostname</br>verification check.</br>

mountpoint.description:
When publishing or subscribing, prefix all topics with a mountpoint string.
The prefixed string will be removed from the topic name when the message
is delivered to the subscriber. The mountpoint is a way that users can use
to implement isolation of message routing between different listeners.
For example if a client A subscribes to `t` with `listeners.tcp..mountpoint`
set to `some_tenant`, then the client actually subscribes to the topic
`some_tenant/t`. Similarly, if another client B (connected to the same listener
as the client A) sends a message to topic `t`, the message is routed
to all the clients subscribed `some_tenant/t`, so client A will receive the
message, with topic name `t`.
Set to `""` to disable the feature.

Variables in mountpoint string:
- ${clientid}: clientid
- ${username}: username
mountpoint.label: mountpoint

proxy_protocol_timeout.description: </br>Timeout for proxy protocol. EMQX will close the TCP connection if proxy protocol packet is not received within the timeout.</br>

authentication.description: </br>Per-listener authentication override.</br>Authentication can be one single authenticator instance or a chain of authenticators as an array.</br>When authenticating a login (username, client ID, etc.) the authenticators are checked in the configured order.</br></br>

If an automatic cluster discovery mechanism is being used (such as etcd),

max_topic_alias.description: Maximum topic alias, 0 means no topic alias supported.

retain_available.description: Whether to enable support for MQTT retained message.

strict_mode.description: Parse MQTT messages in strict mode.</br>When set to true, invalid utf8 strings in for example client ID, topic name, etc. will cause the client to be disconnected

response_information.description: Specify the response information returned to the client. This feature is disabled if is set to "". Applies only to clients using MQTT 5.0.

server_keepalive.description: The keep alive that EMQX requires the client to use. If configured as disabled, it means that the keep alive specified by the client will be used. Requires Server Keep Alive in MQTT 5.0, so it is only applicable to clients using MQTT 5.0 protocol.

keepalive_backoff.description: The backoff multiplier used by the broker to determine the client keep alive timeout. If EMQX doesn't receive any packet in Keep Alive * Backoff * 2 seconds, EMQX will close the current connection.

max_awaiting_rel.description: Maximum QoS 2 packets (Client -> Broker) awaiting PUBREL.
max_awaiting_rel.label: Max Awaiting PUBREL

await_rel_timeout.description: The QoS 2 messages (Client -> Broker) will be dropped if awaiting PUBREL timeout.
await_rel_timeout.label: Max Awaiting PUBREL TIMEOUT

session_expiry_interval.description: Specifies how long the session will expire after the connection is disconnected, only for non-MQTT 5.0 connections.
session_expiry_interval.label: Session Expiry Interval

max_mqueue_len.description: Maximum queue length. Enqueued messages when persistent client disconnected, or inflight window is full.
max_mqueue_len.label: Max Message Queue Length

mqueue_priorities.description:
Topic priorities. Priority number [1-255]
There's no priority table by default, hence all messages are treated equal.

**NOTE**: Comma and equal signs are not allowed for priority topic names.
**NOTE**: Messages for topics not in the priority table are treated as either highest or lowest priority depending on the configured value for mqtt.mqueue_default_priority.

**Examples**:
To configure "topic/1" > "topic/2":
mqueue_priorities: {"topic/1": 10, "topic/2": 8}
mqueue_priorities.label: Topic Priorities

mqueue_default_priority.description: Default topic priority, which will be used by topics not in Topic Priorities (mqueue_priorities).
mqueue_default_priority.label: Default Topic Priorities

mqueue_store_qos0.description: Specifies whether to store QoS 0 messages in the message queue while the connection is down but the session remains.
mqueue_store_qos0.label: Store QoS 0 Message

use_username_as_clientid.description:
Whether to user Client ID as Username.
This setting takes effect later than Use Peer Certificate as Username (peer_cert_as_username) and Use peer certificate as Client ID (peer_cert_as_clientid).
use_username_as_clientid.label: Use Username as Client ID

peer_cert_as_username.description:
Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Username. Only works for the TLS connection.
Supported configurations are the following:
- cn: Take the CN field of the certificate as Username
- dn: Take the DN field of the certificate as Username
- crt: Take the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Username
- pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format as Username
- md5: Take the MD5 value of the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Username
peer_cert_as_username.label: Use Peer Certificate as Username

peer_cert_as_clientid.description:
Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Client ID. Only works for the TLS connection.
Supported configurations are the following:
- cn: Take the CN field of the certificate as Client ID
- dn: Take the DN field of the certificate as Client ID
- crt: Take the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Client ID
- pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format as Client ID
- md5: Take the MD5 value of the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Client ID
peer_cert_as_clientid.label: Use Peer Certificate as Client ID

enable.description: Set to true or false to disable this auth provider.
enable.label: Enable

enable.description: Enable log handler overload kill feature.
enable.label: Log Handler Overload Kill

mem_size.description: Maximum memory size that the log handler process is allowed to use.
mem_size.label: Log Handler Max Memory Size

restart_after.description: If the handler is terminated, it restarts automatically after a delay specified in milliseconds. The value `infinity` prevents restarts.
restart_after.label: Handler Restart Timer

enable_alarm.description: Enable or disable connection congestion alarm.
enable_alarm.label: Enable/disable congestion alarm

min_alarm_sustain_duration.description: Minimal time before clearing the alarm.</br></br>The alarm is cleared only when there's no pending data in</br>the queue, and at least `min_alarm_sustain_duration`</br>milliseconds passed since the last time we considered the connection "congested".</br></br>This is to avoid clearing and raising the alarm again too often.
min_alarm_sustain_duration.label: Sustain duration

ciphers.description:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma,
or as an array of strings. e.g.
"TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or
["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].

Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the
client and server encrypts information over the network connection.
Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the
application's data security, confidentiality and performance.

The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format).
All default values and examples provided by EMQX config
documentation are all in OpenSSL format.

NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with
specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3')
incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped.
For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions,
configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.


NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384,
RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256,
RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA,
RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

NOTE: QUIC listener supports only 'tlsv1.3' ciphers

idle_timeout.description: </br>Close transport-layer connections from the clients that have not sent MQTT CONNECT</br>message within this interval.</br>
idle_timeout.label: Idle Timeout

bind.description: </br>IP address and port for the listening socket.</br>
bind.label: IP address and port

acceptors.description: </br>The size of the listener's receiving pool.</br>
acceptors.label: Acceptors Num

max_connections.description: </br>The maximum number of concurrent connections allowed by the listener.</br>
max_connections.label: Max connections

mountpoint.description:
When publishing or subscribing, prefix all topics with a mountpoint string.
The prefixed string will be removed from the topic name when the message
is delivered to the subscriber. The mountpoint is a way that users can use
to implement isolation of message routing between different listeners.
For example if a client A subscribes to `t` with `listeners.tcp..mountpoint`
set to `some_tenant`, then the client actually subscribes to the topic
`some_tenant/t`. Similarly, if another client B (connected to the same listener
as the client A) sends a message to topic `t`, the message is routed
to all the clients subscribed `some_tenant/t`, so client A will receive the
message, with topic name `t`.
Set to `""` to disable the feature.

Variables in mountpoint string:
- ${clientid}: clientid
- ${username}: username
mountpoint.label: mountpoint

zone.description: </br>The configuration zone to which the listener belongs.</br>
zone.label: Zone

bytes_in.description: The bytes_in limiter.</br>This is used to limit the inbound bytes rate for this EMQX node.</br>Once the limit is reached, the restricted client will be slow down even be hung for a while.
bytes_in.label: Bytes In

message_in.description: The message in limiter.</br>This is used to limit the inbound message numbers for this EMQX node</br>Once the limit is reached, the restricted client will be slow down even be hung for a while.
message_in.label: Message In

connection.description: The connection limiter.</br>This is used to limit the connection rate for this EMQX node.</br>Once the limit is reached, new connections will be refused
connection.label: Connection

message_routing.description: The message routing limiter.</br>This is used to limit the forwarding rate for this EMQX node.</br>Once the limit is reached, new publish will be refused
message_routing.label: Message Routing

batch.description: The batch limiter.</br>This is used for EMQX internal batch operation</br>e.g. limit the retainer's deliver rate
batch.label: Batch

mqtt_path.description:
WebSocket's MQTT protocol path. So the address of EMQX Broker's WebSocket is:
ws://{ip}:{port}/mqtt
mqtt_path.label: WS MQTT Path

mqtt_piggyback.description: </br>Whether a WebSocket message is allowed to contain multiple MQTT packets.</br>
mqtt_piggyback.label: MQTT Piggyback

compress.description:
If true, compress WebSocket messages using zlib.
The configuration items under deflate_opts belong to the compression-related parameter configuration.
compress.label: Ws compress

idle_timeout.description: </br>Close transport-layer connections from the clients that have not sent MQTT CONNECT</br>message within this interval.</br>
idle_timeout.label: Idle Timeout

max_frame_size.description: </br>The maximum length of a single MQTT packet.</br>
max_frame_size.label: Max frame size

fail_if_no_subprotocol.description:
If true, the server will return an error when
the client does not carry the Sec-WebSocket-Protocol field.

Note: WeChat applet needs to disable this verification.
fail_if_no_subprotocol.label: Fail if no subprotocol

check_origin_enable.description:
If true, origin HTTP header will be
validated against the list of allowed origins configured in check_origins
parameter.
check_origin_enable.label: Check origin

allow_origin_absence.description:
If false and check_origin_enable is
true, the server will reject requests that don't have origin
HTTP header.
allow_origin_absence.label: Allow origin absence

proxy_address_header.description: </br>HTTP header used to pass information about the client IP address.</br>Relevant when the EMQX cluster is deployed behind a load-balancer.</br>
proxy_address_header.label: Proxy address header

proxy_port_header.description: </br>HTTP header used to pass information about the client port.</br>Relevant when the EMQX cluster is deployed behind a load-balancer.</br>
proxy_port_header.label: Proxy port header

enable.description: Ignore or enable this listener
enable.label: Enable

bind.description: Port without IP(18083) or port with specified IP(127.0.0.1:18083).
bind.label: Bind

num_acceptors.description: Socket acceptor pool size for TCP protocols.
num_acceptors.label: Number of acceptors

backlog.description: Defines the maximum length that the queue of pending connections can grow to.
backlog.label: Backlog

inet6.description: Enable IPv6 support, default is false, which means IPv4 only.

ipv6_v6only.description: Disable IPv4-to-IPv6 mapping for the listener.
ipv6_v6only.label: IPv6 only

cacertfile.description: </br>Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.</br>The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates.</br>Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted.</br>There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because</br>the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).</br>NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect</br>already established connections.</br>
cacertfile.label: CACertfile

certfile.description: </br>PEM format certificates chain file.</br>The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate</br>issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning</br>of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on.</br>Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of</br>the file if it is to be added.</br>
certfile.label: Certfile

depth.description: </br>Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly; if 1 the path can be PEER, CA, ROOT-CA; if 2 the path can be PEER, CA, CA, ROOT-CA, and so on. The default value is 10.</br>
depth.label: CACert Depth

password.description: </br>String containing the user's password.</br>Only used if the private key file is password-protected.</br>

By enabling secure renegotiation,</br>you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.</br>
secure_renegotiate.label: SSL renegotiate

to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman
key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters
are used.

dhfile.label: SSL dhfile

honor_cipher_order.label: SSL honor cipher order

client_renegotiation.description: </br>In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,</br>the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.</br>This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.</br>The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,</br>but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.</br>The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in</br>long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on</br>the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.</br>
client_renegotiation.label: SSL client renegotiation

flapping_detect.description: This config controls the allowed maximum number of `CONNECT` packets received</br>from the same clientid in a time frame defined by `window_time`.</br>After the limit is reached, successive `CONNECT` requests are forbidden</br>(banned) until the end of the time period defined by `ban_time`.
flapping_detect.label: flapping_detect

force_shutdown.description: When the process message queue length, or the memory bytes</br>reaches a certain value, the process is forced to close.</br></br>Note: "message queue" here refers to the "message mailbox"</br>of the Erlang process, not the `mqueue` of QoS 1 and QoS 2.
force_shutdown.label: force_shutdown

conn_congestion.description: Settings for `conn_congestion` alarm.</br></br>Sometimes the MQTT connection (usually an MQTT subscriber) may</br>get "congested", because there are too many packets to be sent.</br>The socket tries to buffer the packets until the buffer is</br>full. If more packets arrive after that, the packets will be</br>"pending" in the queue, and we consider the connection</br>congested.</br></br>Note: `sndbuf` can be set to larger value if the</br>alarm is triggered too often.</br>The name of the alarm is of format `conn_congestion/<ClientID>/<Username>`,</br>where the `<ClientID>` is the client ID of the congested MQTT connection,</br>and `<Username>` is the username or `unknown_user`.
conn_congestion.label: conn_congestion

force_gc.description: Force garbage collection in MQTT connection process after</br> they process certain number of messages or bytes of data.
force_gc.label: force_gc

overload_protection.description: Overload protection mechanism monitors the load of the system and temporarily</br>disables some features (such as accepting new connections) when the load is high.
overload_protection.label: overload_protection

mqtt.description:
Global MQTT configuration.
The configs here work as default values which can be overridden
in zone configs
mqtt.label: mqtt

stats.description: Enable/disable statistic data collection.</br>Statistic data such as message receive/send count/rate etc. It provides insights of system performance and helps to diagnose issues. You can find statistic data from the dashboard, or from the '/stats' API.
stats.label: stats
